required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Role of Massage in Increasing Total Motile Sperm Count of IUI
clinical_study.official_title: The Role of Massage in Increasing Total Motile Sperm Count of Intrauterine Insemination

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this prospective, randomized study, was to determine if neck and shoulder massage performed within 15 minutes of semen sample collection will increase the semen volume, and therefore increase the total motile sperm available for insemination as a result of decreased stress.

primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome variable is total motile sperm count, which is determined based on the semen volume, concentration, and motility.

secondary_outcome.description: Pregnancy rate per cycle with intrauterine insemination.

arm_group.description: Professional Swedish massage less than 15 minutes prior to semen collection for intrauterine insemination.
Normal protocol for semen collection prior to intrauterine insemination.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Infertility,
- initiating clomiphene + IUI therapy
- signed study consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe male infertility (baseline semen concentration < 10 million total motile sperm)
- female bilateral tubal occlusion
- failure to ovulate with clomiphene
- failed clomiphene + IUI therapy (three prior cycles with no conception)
- unable to tolerate clomiphene
- unable or unwilling to follow study protocol

facility.name: Women's Institute at Carolinas Medical Center
